facts.text: Appellant is a partner of a firm owning the New India Knitting Mills in Amritsar, with a sister concern J. D. Woollen and Silk Mills owned by a partnership firm of which appellant's minor son is a partner.
On 10-10-1963, J. D. Mills was given an import licence for Rs. 23,480/- for spare parts for Warp Knitting Machine from Germany.
Goods valued at Rs. 11,699/- arrived in Bombay on 16.3.1964.
J.D. Mills arranged clearance through New Suraj Transit Company; Hiro Shahani, employee of clearing agents, became approver.
Bakubhai Ambalal Co. were representatives in India of the machinery manufacturing company.
In July 1963, anonymous petition against the two mills; on 21.11.1963, order by Principal Appraiser for careful watch over imports.
On 30-3-1964, J. D. Mills complained to Deputy Collector about delays; appellant met Deputy Collector protesting scrutiny.
Bill of Entry prepared on 4-6-1964; sent to Special Investigation Branch and back.
Motwani (PW6) examined goods, opined not spare parts but machine in assembled condition; Shed Appraiser agreed.
Clearing agents telephoned appellant, who asked for re-examination; Shahani requested Principal Appraiser Almeida.
Vazirani re-examined, reported; approved by Menon, then Merchant recommended show cause notice for mis-declaration; Almeida approved 9-7-1964; notice issued 17-7-1964.
Appellant reached Bombay on 1-7-1964.
Towards end of July 1964, Central Intelligence Unit constituted; Ramachandra Rao (PW3) transferred, inspected goods 1-8-1964.
On 4-9-1964, directed to search Bakubhai Ambalal, who produced documents.
Appellant asked Shahani on 4th to introduce to Rao; introduction made.
On 13-8-1964, appellant met Rao at Gaylord restaurant; alleged offer of bribe Rs. 5000/-; Rao reported to Sonavne at 1.30 p.m.
On 14-8-1964, appellant and Shahani met Rao at Gaylord; appellant passed two envelopes containing Rs. 2500/- each; Jog recovered them.
PWs 4 and 5 (Income-tax officers) overheard as panch witnesses.
Charge-sheet filed 30-10-1964; Shahani arrested 24-11-1964, released on bail; statement January 1965, confession 19-3-1965; pardon granted 15-4-1965.
Appellant convicted by Special Judge under S. 165-A IPC, RI 1 year, fine Rs.10,000; High Court upheld conviction, reduced RI to 6 months.
Shahani applied for reward 21-5-1965, received Rs.500, Rs.500, Rs.350 on 7-6-1965; applied for clearing agent licence.
Appellant applied for production of documents on 20-9-1965 and 22-9-1965; dismissed by Special Judge.
High Court on 11-6-1968 allowed portions of CIU file (Ex.67,68); Shahani and Rao re-examined.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant made an offer of bribe to Rao on 13-8-1964 and gave the bribe on 14-8-1964.
Whether evidence of Rao and Shahani is reliable, considering conspiracy allegations and privilege claims under Evidence Act.
Whether production of CIU file documents affects the prosecution case.

petitioner_arguments.text: No meeting between appellant and Rao on 13-8-1964; charge result of conspiracy between Rao (to advance career) and Shahani (for reward and licence).
Appellant asked for papers on two consignments, but Shahani brought envelopes with currency notes; reaction consistent with innocence.
Rao's evidence contradictory to panchnama and PWs 4,5; Madanlal not in Bombay.
Bribe offered only to avoid harassment; reconsidered payment post-clearance.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant offered bribe on 13-8-1964 and gave on 14-8-1964; corroborated by panchnama and PWs.

court_reasoning.text: High Court order allowing portions of CIU file incorrect as it contravenes s.124 Evidence Act; does not affect merits as documents do not impinge on guilt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Privilege under ss.123-125 Evidence Act; no need to overrule in this case.

court_reasoning.text: Shahani's informer role and reward do not affect core issue of bribe offer and payment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Crucial question is events of 13th and 14th August 1964.

court_reasoning.text: Rao reported immediately to superiors; unlikely to fabricate without meeting; no motive for false implication risking Rs.5000.
No contradiction between Rao's evidence and panchnama/PWs 4,5; allowance for memory in crowded restaurant.
Appellant's reaction not of innocent; inconsistent story on papers/envelopes.
No harassment; appellant trying to influence clearance of misdeclared goods.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sentence of 6 months RI appropriate; not like entrapment cases.

holdings.text: Appellant guilty under S.165-A IPC; conviction and sentence of 6 months RI upheld.
CIU file portions should not have been admitted; does not weaken prosecution.
No reduction in sentence below 6 months.

precedents_cited.relevance: On scope of court powers to examine privileged documents under Evidence Act.
On scope of court powers to examine privileged documents.
Not a case of deliberate temptation into bribery by law guardians.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant convicted for criminal misconduct by public servant in accepting bribe.

statutes_cited.name: Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Privilege claimed for official communications; court holds s.124 contravened by disclosure.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld the Bombay High Court's conviction under S.165-A IPC and sentence of 6 months rigorous imprisonment (reduced from 1 year), finding guilt established beyond reasonable doubt based on reliable evidence of bribe offer and payment.

key_quotes.text: "The crucial question is whether the appellant did make an offer of a bribe to Rao on 13-8-1964 and did give the bribe on the 14th."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines core issue of the case.

key_quotes.text: "We are satisfied that the conclusion arrived at by both the courts below about the appellant's guilt is correct and it has been established beyond all reasonable doubt."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A witness is not like a tape-recorder."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains allowance for discrepancies in evidence recollection.
